0.text:
Let's make it clap! Let's make it clap! It's
Q & A Tuesday time!

10.text:
This question comes come from Olivia and Olivia
writes,

13.text:
Q: "Hi, Marie, I've been loving all the wisdom
you share in your videos and hope you can

17.text:
help me with the dilemma that I've been facing
lately? I'm in the process of building a business

21.text:
I'm super passionate about, Roystonwriting.com
and in a few months I'll have enough money

29.text:
saved up to devote myself full-time to its
launch.

33.text:
If I'm careful with my budget that is, so
far I've invested money in educating myself

38.text:
with programs, not to mention reading tons
of books. Now, I'm getting to the point where

42.text:
I have to start making decisions about things
like getting professional photos taken or

46.text:
hiring someone to do a few videos for my website,
or figuring out a way to do these things myself.

52.text:
My question is is there a reliable way to
know what's worth outsourcing and what I should

58.text:
just do myself when money is tight? You're
the best, Olivia.

62.text:
A: How great is that question! In general
you want to keep your business as lean and

65.text:
mean as you can. Especially in the beginning,
so you want to get as much cash flow coming

69.text:
in and keep your expenses very low. Knowing
what to outsource and what not to is really

74.text:
about four key things; first, you want to
hire out what simply can't be done by you.

79.text: You have no capabilities and you have no interest.

81.text:
Let me tell you a little story about how I
hired things out when I was first designing

86.text:
my book, So Make Every Man Want You, How To
Be So Irresistible You Barely Will Keep From

90.text:
Dating Yourself started off as a self-published
book. And, I remember thinking to myself you

96.text:
know, "I'm not a designer and I'm not a copyeditor,
and I really need to hire those things out."

101.text:
So I budgeted and here is the vintage version
of my book. Not many people have seen this

106.text:
puppy! So, I got like a little stock photo
and I got a designer, and I really told them

110.text:
exactly how I wanted this thing to look because
it was important for me to have a super-high

116.text:
I wanted this puppy to look just as good as
any book that was in Barnes Noble. And, this

122.text:
is the modern day version of Make Every Man
Want You in bookstores all across America.

128.text:
But wait there's more! Yes, this is the French
version of Make Every Man Want You, oui, oui!

134.text:
And yes, this is the Chinese version of Make
Every Man Want You because I don't know how

138.text: to do a Chinese accent. Oui!

142.text:
Two, you want to hire out simple tasks that
really should be done by someone else like

148.text:
customer service or even a personal assistant.
That'll really free up your time to focus

152.text:
on the big items. Also, remember in our global
marketplace it is so easy to find fantastic

157.text:
talent for reasonable prices. Two places that
I can recommend for you are oDesk.com and

164.text:
HireMyMom.com. Three, remember that it's totally
okay to do things yourself if it sounds like

170.text:
fun, you have an interest, and it's going
to feed your soul and your bigger vision.

174.text:
You may have heard some other advice about
outsourcing. For example, if you earn about

179.text:
$50 dollars an hour in your business activities.
Other business gurus may suggest that if you

184.text:
have something on your plate that you can
pay someone else to do for say $20 bucks an

188.text:
hour, that you definitely should pay that
person. Here's why I disagree, slightly with

193.text: that. Another story from Marie Land:

195.text:
It was 2008 when I first started experimenting
with video marketing and you can see a lovely

200.text:
little example of that, my older videos. Right
here! I didn't have fancy editors. I didn't

206.text:
have a film crew. I didn't do any things that
I did now. I started with just my Mac and

211.text:
a flip camera, and editing myself on imovie.
Why? Because I really wanted to learn it,

217.text:
it brought me pleasure. I wanted to understand
how to craft a story.

220.text:
I wanted to be able to upload videos on the
fly and I wasn't sure if this medium was right

225.text:
for me.
So rather than hire someone to do it and I

228.text:
could have technically afforded it at that
point. I figured I wanted to do it myself

231.text:
because I really wanted to learn. So for me,
shooting and editing my own videos in the

235.text:
beginning was a fantastic break from all the
writing that I normally do for my business.

239.text:
So while I understand that philosophy and
agree with it sometimes, it's important to

244.text:
hang onto things that sound like fun and you
actually have an interest in. Finally, number

249.text:
four is you have to trust your gut to know
the difference. It is vitally important as

254.text:
an entrepreneur to understand how to allocate
your resources so you can stay profitable

259.text:
not only for the short-term but for the long-term,
too.

262.text:
So Olivia, that's the A to your Q! Congratulations
on your new business and thank you everybody

270.text:
for watching! If you're digging these videos,
give it a little thumbs up! If you really

275.text:
dig these videos, you should share it with
all of your friends in social media land.

279.text:
Yay!! And of course, if you're not yet on
the newsletter list, come on over to marieforleo.com,

286.text:
jump on it! I will see you next time. Thanks
again for watching.

290.text:
Hey, RHH LI.VE is coming up! Are you coming?
Go to rhhlive.com for details.

307.text:
So, I'm going to tell you a little question.
Oop, I'm going to tell you a little question!

321.text:
I'm going to tell you that question! I don't
ask questions, I tell you questions!
